item.title: Emoji Generator with AI (emoji.fly.dev)
item.description: A Collection of Diverse Emojis in Slackmoji AI Edition
item.content:encoded:
This collection of Slackmoji AI Edition features a wide range of emojis, including various characters, objects, and concepts. Some notable emojis include a bender, speedometer, flag of the most evil country, confused face, demon, Entei, Gopher, and a gray cat with a very long tongue. There are also emojis representing famous personalities like Donald Trump and Philip J. Fry. Additionally, there are emojis that depict controversial or inappropriate themes such as a gay Hitler and a Nazi. Overall, this collection offers a diverse range of emojis for users to express themselves in Slack conversations.

item.title: Procreate Dreams (procreate.com)
item.description: Introducing Procreate Dreams: A Powerful Animation App for Creating Hand-Drawn Animations and Motion Graphics
item.content:encoded:
Procreate Dreams is a new animation app that allows users to create hand-drawn animations, motion graphics, and enhance them with photos, videos, and sound. It offers a range of features including drawing and painting tools, multi-touch timeline, audio and video editing capabilities, and stage creation. The app also provides live motion and effects adjustments, keyframes for precise animation control, real-time rendering, and onion skins for easy customization. Procreate Dreams supports text and type animation, as well as the import of custom fonts. It is designed for iPad and Apple Pencil, offering a natural and responsive painting experience. The app will be available for purchase on November 22 for $19.99 USD.

item.title: Aardvark'd: The Fog Creek Documentary, 18 Years Later (mtlynch.io)
item.description: Aardvark'd: The Fog Creek Documentary, 18 Years Later - A Look into the Early Days of Tech Startup Founders
item.content:encoded:
Aardvark'd: The Fog Creek Documentary, 18 Years Later is a documentary film about Fog Creek's summer internship program in 2005. The film captures interviews with individuals who would go on to achieve fame and success in the tech industry. It explores the indie software scene of 2005, featuring Fog Creek Software, Y Combinator, and the launch of reddit. The documentary showcases the vulnerability and uncertainty experienced by tech startup founders during their early days. Despite its flaws, Aardvark'd provides a relatable and engaging look into the challenges of launching a software product. The film ends without a clear resolution, leaving viewers wondering about the outcome of the interns' project. The documentary includes insightful quotes from Paul Graham and Aaron Swartz. Surprisingly, Fog Creek did not finance the film, and the filmmaker recently uploaded it for free on YouTube.

98 Points | 22 comments

item.title: Large Language Models as Optimizers. +50% on Big Bench Hard (arxiv.org)
item.description: Leveraging Large Language Models as Optimizers: Introducing Optimization by PROmpting (OPRO)
item.content:encoded:
The paper introduces Optimization by PROmpting (OPRO), a method that leverages large language models (LLMs) as optimizers. OPRO uses natural language prompts to generate new solutions in each optimization step. The authors demonstrate the effectiveness of OPRO on linear regression, traveling salesman problems, and prompt optimization tasks. They show that prompts optimized by OPRO outperform human-designed prompts by up to 8% on GSM8K and by up to 50% on Big-Bench Hard tasks. The paper falls under the categories of Machine Learning, Artificial Intelligence, and Computation and Language.

3 Points | 0 comments

item.title: Bun v1.0.0 (github.com)
item.description: Bun v1.0 Release: Bug Fixes, Improvements, and New Features
item.content:encoded:
Bun v1.0 is now available for installation and upgrade. The release notes highlight various bug fixes and improvements, including fixes for sourcemaps, hot reloading, module imports, debugger support, and more. The release also brings in uSockets and uWebSockets forks into Bun's repository. The changelog lists all the changes made from version 0.8.1 to 1.0.0. The release has seen contributions from new contributors as well. Overall, Bun v1.0 offers several enhancements and bug fixes for a better development experience.

133 Points | 49 comments

item.title: Bees struggle to find flowers because of air pollution (www.birmingham.ac.uk)
item.description: Air pollution degrades floral scent, making it difficult for bees to find flowers
item.content:encoded:
Air pollution degrades the scent of flowers, making it difficult for bees to find them, according to a study by the UK Centre for Ecology & Hydrology and several universities. The research found that ground-level ozone, formed when nitrogen oxide emissions react with volatile organic compounds, changes the size and scent of floral odour plumes. This reduced honeybees' ability to recognise odours by up to 90% from just a few metres away. The study suggests that ozone could have a negative impact on wildflower abundance and crop yields, with implications for food security. The research highlights the need to take action on air pollution to protect pollinators and preserve biodiversity.

78 Points | 12 comments

item.title: Move over lithium-ion: Zinc-air batteries a cheaper and safer alternative (www.ecu.edu.au)
item.description: Zinc-air batteries identified as cheaper and safer alternative to lithium-ion batteries
item.content:encoded:
Zinc-air batteries have been identified as a cheaper and safer alternative to lithium-ion batteries for powering electric vehicles, according to a study by Edith Cowan University. The research found that zinc-air batteries, which use a combination of sustainable and cost-effective materials, offer improved lifespan and performance compared to lithium-ion batteries. The breakthrough design of these batteries, using new materials such as carbon, iron, and cobalt, has overcome previous limitations related to power output and lifespan. The use of abundant zinc resources in countries like Australia, along with the ubiquity of air, makes zinc-air batteries a viable and reliable energy storage solution. This development contributes to building a sustainable society and reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

item.title: The thinking path (www.robinsloan.com)
item.description: Robin Sloan's Excitement for His New Novel and Reflections on Creativity and Goodness
item.content:encoded:
Robin Sloan announces the upcoming publication of his new novel in June 2024 and shares his excitement. He discusses the influence of fantasy sagas on his previous novels and explores the idea of going beyond homage to actively participate in the genre. Sloan plans to create a rich introduction and companion for his new novel, incorporating various influences and media. He also reviews a novel by Michiko Aoyama and reflects on the need for creative investigations of decency and goodness. Sloan asks for nominations of great author websites and discusses the problem-solving power of walking. He concludes by highlighting the quality of science journalism and sharing an interesting logo treatment for Mattel Electronics.

item.title: PolicyFly (YC W22) Is Hiring a Senior Solutions Engineer (Remote) (www.ycombinator.com)
item.description: PolicyFly Seeks Senior Solutions Engineer to Modernize Specialty Insurance
item.content:encoded:
PolicyFly is seeking a Senior Solutions Engineer to lead the post-sales onboarding and implementation process for clients. The role involves developing a repeatable process for client onboarding, mapping client requirements, building insurance applications, and providing technical feedback to improve the onboarding experience. The ideal candidate should have experience in property and casualty insurance, scripting data processing pipelines, writing unit tests, and building enterprise applications. The company is focused on modernizing specialty insurance by providing immediate value to insurers and automating back-office operations. PolicyFly is a distributed remote team with a long-term vision for building network effects in the insurance industry.

1 Points | 0 comments

item.title: China's ancient water pipe networks show no evidence of a centralized authority (phys.org)
item.description: Ancient Chinese water pipes reveal neolithic communities' engineering capabilities without centralized authority
item.content:encoded:
Ancient ceramic water pipes discovered in China reveal that neolithic communities were capable of complex engineering without a centralized state authority, according to a study by University College London. The network of pipes and drainage ditches at the site of Pingliangtai, dating back 4,000 years, demonstrates communal cooperation in building and maintaining the system. The settlement shows little evidence of social hierarchy, with uniformly small houses and no signs of significant inequality. The discovery challenges the belief that only centralized states could undertake such engineering feats, highlighting the capabilities of more egalitarian and communal societies. The advanced water management system at Pingliangtai required significant community-wide planning and coordination.

179 Points | 112 comments

item.title: How Query Engines Work (howqueryengineswork.com)
item.description: How Query Engines Work: A Comprehensive Guide
item.content:encoded:
This book provides an in-depth exploration of how query engines work, covering topics such as Apache Arrow, type systems, data sources, logical plans, DataFrames, physical plans, query planning, query optimizers, query execution, SQL support, parallel and distributed query execution, testing, benchmarks, and further resources. The author expresses gratitude to their family, Matthew Powers, the Apache Arrow community, and colleagues at RMS for their support and inspiration. The book is available for purchase in multiple formats.

207 Points | 32 comments

item.title: A Study of Malicious Code in PyPI Ecosystem (about.honywen.com)
item.description: Understanding the State of Malicious Code in the PyPI Ecosystem
item.content:encoded:
This empirical study examines the characteristics and current state of malicious code in the PyPI ecosystem. The researchers collected a dataset of 4,669 malicious package files and classified them into five categories based on their behavior. The study found that over 50% of the malicious code exhibited multiple malicious behaviors, with information stealing and command execution being common. The analysis revealed that 74.81% of the malicious packages successfully entered end-user projects through source code installation, posing significant security risks. Furthermore, many reported malicious packages persisted in PyPI mirror servers globally, even after being discovered. The study provides insights into the lifecycle of malicious code in the PyPI ecosystem and suggests mitigations to enhance the security of the Python open-source ecosystem.

3 Points | 1 comments

item.title: TSMC warns AI chip crunch will last another 18 months (www.theregister.com)
item.description: TSMC warns AI chip crunch will last another 18 months
item.content:encoded:
TSMC warns that the shortage of advanced packaging capacity will continue to impact the availability of high-end GPUs until at least the end of 2024. The issue lies in the lack of capacity to stitch the silicon together, rather than a shortage of chips. TSMC can only meet about 80% of the demand for its chip on wafer on substrate (CoWoS) packaging technology, which is used in advanced chips for AI workloads. TSMC expects additional CoWoS capacity to come online within the next 18 months. This shortage affects not only Nvidia but also AMD's upcoming Instinct MI300-series accelerators.

57 Points | 30 comments

item.title: NSO group iPhone zero-click, zero-day exploit captured in the wild (citizenlab.ca)
item.description: Apple Releases Update to Address Zero-Click Vulnerability Exploited by NSO Group's Pegasus Spyware
item.content:encoded:
Apple issues update to fix zero-click vulnerability exploited by NSO Group's Pegasus spyware. The exploit chain, known as BLASTPASS, targeted iPhones running the latest iOS version without user interaction. Citizen Lab discovered and disclosed the vulnerability to Apple, who issued two CVEs related to the exploit. Users are urged to update their devices immediately and consider enabling Lockdown Mode for added protection. The incident highlights the ongoing targeting of civil society organizations by sophisticated cyber threats. Apple's response and collaboration with Citizen Lab are commended.

1203 Points | 652 comments

item.title: Show HN: Rivet – open-source AI Agent dev env with real-world applications (rivet.ironcladapp.com)
item.description: Rivet: A Visual Programming Environment for Building AI Agents with LLMs
item.content:encoded:
Rivet is a visual programming environment for building AI agents with LLMs. It allows teams to design, debug, and collaborate on complex LLM prompt graphs and deploy them in their own environment. The tool offers features like visualizing and building complex chains, remote debugging, and collaboration through versioning in a team's repository. Rivet has received positive feedback from users who appreciate its visual nature, debugging capabilities, and collaborative features. It has been used by Ironclad to develop their virtual contract assistant, Contract AI. Developers can easily get started with Rivet by following the provided guide and integrating it into their applications.

item.title: LibreWolf – Custom version of Firefox, focused on privacy, security and freedom (librewolf.net)
item.description: LibreWolf: A Privacy-Focused Custom Version of Firefox
item.content:encoded:
LibreWolf is a custom version of Firefox that prioritizes privacy, security, and user freedom. It aims to enhance protection against tracking and fingerprinting techniques, remove telemetry and data collection, and disable anti-freedom features. The browser includes privacy-conscious search providers and a content blocker. It is regularly updated for the latest security and features, and is open source, allowing community participation. Contributions are welcome, and the project provides support for various operating systems. LibreWolf is not affiliated with Mozilla.

item.title: H2Fly – Breaking the Hydrogen Barrier (www.h2fly.de)
item.description: Breaking the Hydrogen Barrier: Hydrogen's Potential to Decarbonize Aviation
item.content:encoded:
Hydrogen is presented as the best solution for decarbonizing aviation due to its zero-emissions, safety, economic viability, low-noise profile, and ability to enable new regional air mobility connections. H2FLY, a German developer, has successfully completed the world's first piloted flight of an electric aircraft powered by liquid hydrogen. They have been researching and refining a hydrogen-electric powertrain system for over a decade, and their fuel cell system converts clean hydrogen into electricity to power their demonstrator aircraft HY4. This achievement proves that zero-emission aviation is within reach. H2FLY's vision is to unlock the era of sustainable air travel by developing qualified hydrogen-electric powertrains for aviation.

8 Points | 2 comments

item.title: Price shock: IBM to increase cloud costs by up to 26% in 2024 – CIO (www.cio.com)
item.description: IBM to Increase Cloud Costs by Up to 26% in 2024
item.content:encoded:
IBM plans to increase its cloud services costs by up to 26% in 2024, affecting infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS) and platform-as-a-service (PaaS) offerings. The price hike will be steeper for international customers compared to those in the US. PaaS services, including Kubernetes Services and RedHat OpenShift, will see a 3% price increase globally. For IaaS offerings, the price hikes will apply to bare metal servers, virtual server instances, file and block storage, and networking infrastructure. The price changes will vary across different data centers, with some experiencing increases of up to 7.5%. IBM's Cloud Object Storage service will also see price increases of 25% to 26% globally. This move follows similar price hikes by other technology vendors to combat inflation and rising costs.

81 Points | 54 comments

item.title: Dating app Grindr loses nearly half its staff after trying to force RTO (www.cnn.com)
item.description: Grindr Loses Nearly Half of Staff After Enforcing Return-to-Office Policy
item.content:encoded:
LGBTQ dating app Grindr loses nearly half of its staff after implementing a return-to-office policy. The policy required employees to either relocate to designated 'hub' cities or leave the company. Around 80 out of 178 workers were forced to leave as a result. The return-to-work policy is seen as retaliatory by the Communications Workers of America (CWA) in response to a union drive at the company. The CWA has filed an unfair labor practice charge against Grindr. This situation reflects the ongoing tensions between employers and workers regarding return-to-office policies in the post-pandemic era.

87 Points | 95 comments

item.title: Digging through the New York Times morgue (buttondown.email)
item.description: Uncovering Treasures: Exploring the Transition to Computer Phototypesetting at The New York Times
item.content:encoded:
Researcher uncovers treasures from the transition to computer phototypesetting in the 1970s while digging through the New York Times morgue. The morgue contains millions of newspaper clippings, photographs, and other materials organized by subject matter. The researcher explores the transition from hot metal composition to computer phototypesetting at The Times in the 1970s, delving into the reasons behind the newspaper's delayed adoption of the technology. The visit to the morgue reveals internal publications documenting the transition and photos of the typesetting room. The researcher shares their process of organizing and analyzing the materials for their book on the topic.

25 Points | 7 comments
